text:
<!here> hello there everyone! welcome to the february AMA with <@U01AKNHR58D> and <@UL1CGCATB> from <https://www.animalz.co/|Animalz>. please drop your question in the channel and kristen and mark can answer in the thread

here's a little back ground on each of these excellent people:

<@U01AKNHR58D> has 10+ years of experience in B2B SaaS Marketing for customers like Wistia, Ovia Health, and Tettra. Though she loves content marketing, her real “zone of genius” is around building high performance teams: hiring great people, creating clear goals and systems, and coaching others to do their best work. She loves bringing these interests together at Animalz, working with some of the best SaaS companies out there. follow her on twitter <https://twitter.com/thecrafty|@thecrafty>

<@UL1CGCATB> is a Content Strategist at Animalz. He’s been working in marketing for almost a decade with stops in advertising and social media during that time, but content marketing is his true love. At Animalz, Mark leads a team that specializes in helping SaaS companies launch new content marketing programs. follow him on twitter <https://twitter.com/mrog91588|@mrog91588>

Animalz is a sponsor of this slack group (we really appreciate their support!) and is hiring for a few open roles right now. you can check those out at <https://jobs.superpath.co/company/animalz>

text:
ooo, i've actually got a good answer here.

Early my contact career I put together a really complex content strategy because I confused quality with complexity. it took months of work to produce all this complex content and the result was a total fail. i mean, total failure. it got like 100 pageviews across all the content.

I realized that I over-indexed on complexity, rather than following search intent and having a solid understanding of what quality really is

elements.text:

I realized that I over-indexed on complexity, rather than following search intent and having a solid understanding of what quality really is

text:
maybe not so much a framework, but i fully believe that you need to create different content based on the distribution channel.

SEO content needs to be keyword based (obviously), and that usually doesn't work on social, or in newsletters, or internet forums.

For small, but growing companies, search can be a really challenging channel. I usually recommend taking some big swings with content designed to capture attention on social or in newsletters.

Newsletters are totally an underutilized distribution tactic right now

elements.text:

text: Sometimes I feel "content specialist" is a new title to what people were already doing before: writing advertising copy and other formats like case studies, webinars, blog content, etc (of course, also drawing strategies and coordinating actions). elements.text: Sometimes I feel "content specialist" is a new title to what people were already doing before: writing advertising copy and other formats like case studies, webinars, blog content, etc (of course, also drawing strategies and coordinating actions). text: Hi! 7-year B2B content agency alum here :slightly_smiling_face: It's a fun world to work in. When I managed an agency team, one of my challenges (for myself and people I managed) was balancing TODAY vs THE FUTURE -- or client work/production vs the more creative, explorative side of working for an agency. How do you help people manage the daily reality of their work load while still continuously learning and experimenting so they can give clients forward-thinking strategic advice?

elements.text: Hi! 7-year B2B content agency alum here

It's a fun world to work in. When I managed an agency team, one of my challenges (for myself and people I managed) was balancing TODAY vs THE FUTURE -- or client work/production vs the more creative, explorative side of working for an agency. How do you help people manage the daily reality of their work load while still continuously learning and experimenting so they can give clients forward-thinking strategic advice?

text:
Totally, the daily carnage was just one of those swing for the fences ideas that I really like for small growing companies.

we were an agency that had zero brand awareness. i knew traditional content marketing could work, but it would take a long time. so we started playing with other styles of content. this was before newsletters were a huge thing. Theskimm was really the only newsletter out at the time.

and quite honestly, we were just like, "why add to the noise of content marketing with more content marketing, when we can sum up the best of the day in theskimm's style?"

elements.text:

text: I'm a very visual learner, so I like reading about other people's approaches and then putting it into practice. for example, ever since I read this, I've approached writing (using this BLUF mindset) differently <https://www.animalz.co/blog/bottom-line-up-front/>

attachments.title: BLUF: The Military Standard That Can Make Your Writing More Powerful - Animalz
attachments.text: BLUF is a military communications acronym—it stands for “bottom line up front”—that’s designed to enforce speed and clarity in reports and emails.

text:
For me, the most important thing to consider is the company's business model. So my strategies always start there.

Freemium needs to treat content differently than sales-driven orgs.

From there, you have to take time to understand the audience. What are their job tasks, where do they go to ask questions, what do they read?

Then, write down the goal of the content strategy. What are you trying to achieve? And I try to make this realistic. A good goal isn't "to change the world through educational content." It's more like, "to drive leads, sales brand awareness, etc. for my company."

Then, understand your constraints. Essentially, what's holding you back from achieving that goal?

elements.text:
For me, the most important thing to consider is the company's business model. So my strategies always start there.

Freemium needs to treat content differently than sales-driven orgs.

From there, you have to take time to understand the audience. What are their job tasks, where do they go to ask questions, what do they read?

Then, write down the goal of the content strategy. What are you trying to achieve? And I try to make this realistic. A good goal isn't "to change the world through educational content." It's more like, "to drive leads, sales brand awareness, etc. for my company."

Then, understand your constraints. Essentially, what's holding you back from achieving that goal?

Generally we see companies that have a content marketing team that tends to be siloed from their product marketing team, when these two depts. should be tied together to reel visitors back to their product/services with their content.

What should content marketers be demanding from their product marketing team?
